<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 1 / 4>

Teaching the Unknown: Risk and Agency 
in the Time of AI in the Classroom
Brian Ballsun-Stanton and Jodie Torrington
Introduction 
Generative artificial intelligence (AI) has disrupted education systems worldwide, 
necessitating novel pedagogical approaches. While education leaders grapple with broad 
concepts of AI literacy and assessment reform (Lodge et al., 2023; Liu & Bates, 2025; 
UNESCO, 2023), less attention has been paid to the fundamental pedagogical challenges of 
teaching with and about a technology that is characterised by emergent properties, shifting 
capabilities, and inherent uncertainties. This paper argues that effectively teaching with and 
about AI requires pedagogical frameworks specifically designed to embrace uncertainty, 
structure risk-taking, and develop student agency in the face of technological indeterminacy. 
Drawing on Transformative Learning Theory (Mezirow, 1991) and the epistemological 
framework of the Rumsfeld Matrix (Rumsfeld, 2002), we examine how deliberately decoupling 
task success from assessment outcomes creates educational environments where students can 
develop sophisticated intuitions about AI interaction without the inhibiting effects of graderelated anxieties. This approach directly counters students' initial tendency to defer to AI rather 
than direct it (Torrington et al., 2025), facilitating a shift toward internal AI-Locus of Control 
through structured experimentation with failure.
Theoretical Frameworks
Transformative Learning Theory (Mezirow, 1991, 2018) provides a framework for 
understanding the pedagogical challenges of AI education. Mezirow's theory posits that 
learning occurs through critical reflection on disorienting dilemmas: experiences that disrupt 
existing assumptions and necessitate a re-evaluation of beliefs, values, and perspectives. This 
process involves three interconnected themes relevant to AI education: experiential 
engagement, critical reflection, and rational discourse.
The Rumsfeld Matrix (Rumsfeld, 2002, Pawson et al., 2011) offers a complementary 
epistemological framework for conceptualising the pedagogical challenges of teaching AI 
literacy. The matrix distinguishes between "known knowns" (facts we're aware of and 
understand), "known unknowns" (factors we know exist but don't fully comprehend), 
"unknown knowns" (subconscious knowledge we don't realise we possess), and "unknown 
unknowns" (factors we're unaware of and can't predict). The course deliberately designed 
experiences to transform unknown unknowns into known unknowns: making students aware 
of AI's limitations, biases, and effective interaction patterns through structured experimentation 
and collective reflection.
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 2 / 4>

Methodology
The pedagogical approach was implemented in a 13-week undergraduate Politics and 
International Relations course teaching the pragmatics of AI within a disciplinary lens. 
Students engaged in AI-augmented international relations simulations, using AI to articulate 
different ideological lenses, explore policy options, and analyse outputs for bias and safety 
risks. The course produced three primary data sources for this research: student reflections, 
observations, and annotated AI interaction logs.
The core methodological innovation was the deliberate decoupling of success in AI activities 
from assessment outcomes. Students were graded exclusively on their reflections about their 
experiences—both successes and failures—rather than on the quality of AI outputs or 
simulation outcomes. This approach required significant time investment in building student 
trust; it took approximately eight weeks of the 13-week course before students fully accepted 
that experimentation and failure were truly valued in the assessment scheme.
Pedagogical Design
The course's pedagogical design was built around three interconnected approaches to teaching 
under conditions of technological uncertainty:
Risk-Embracing Assessment Structure
The foundation of our approach was an assessment structure that explicitly rewarded risktaking and critical reflection. Assessment tasks evaluated students' ability to articulate their 
learning from both successful and unsuccessful AI interactions, creating a psychological safety 
zone where experimental failure carried no grade penalties. As one student reflected, "I think 
I've learned more in my failures in this class than in what went right. Being able to fail has been 
really advantageous to my learning" (Student reflection, Week 9).
This approach directly countered students' initial tendency to avoid risk and defer to AI outputs. 
By evaluating reflection quality rather than AI interaction outcomes, we created conditions 
where students could develop sophisticated intuitions about AI capabilities without inhibition. 
Intentional Classroom Cultural Development
Course design intentionally fostered a community of practice centred on shared 
experimentation with AI. Each class began with a "Show me your prompts!" discussion where 
students shared AI interactions from the previous week, analysing both effective and 
ineffective prompting strategies. This practice created a collaborative learning environment 
where mistakes and failures became valuable community resources rather than sources of 
embarrassment.
The instructor deliberately modelled vulnerability by sharing personal AI interaction failures, 
normalising experimentation and establishing trust. As the semester progressed, students 
increasingly engaged in peer-to-peer learning, with more experienced students offering
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 3 / 4>

guidance to those struggling with effective AI prompting. This socio-constructivist approach 
facilitated the development of shared knowledge about effective AI interaction patterns.
Navigating Uncertainty
The course employed structured but open-ended simulations to navigate the "unknown 
unknowns" of AI interaction. Students were encouraged to develop explicit expectations for 
AI outputs before prompting, then use the gaps between expectations and reality to refine their 
conceptual understanding of AI capabilities and limitations. This approach shifted students 
from viewing AI as a mysterious black box to seeing it as a tool with predictable patterns of 
behaviour. The 13-week semester provided sufficient duration for students to progress through 
cycles of experimentation, failure, reflection, and reconceptualisation. 
Discussion and Implications
This pedagogical approach carries significant implications for teaching with emerging 
technologies. Traditional education often emphasises certainty, correctness, and predictability; 
qualities fundamentally at odds with the emergent, probabilistic nature of contemporary AI 
systems. By structuring learning experiences around uncertainty and ambiguity, this approach 
prepares students for technological environments characterised by continual change and 
unpredictability.
The findings suggest that developing AI literacy requires not only technical knowledge but also 
epistemic humility: a willingness to engage with uncertainty, recognise limitations, and 
continually reassess assumptions. This perspective aligns with humanistic approaches to 
technology that prioritise human agency over technological determinism.
Significantly, this approach contradicts common institutional responses to AI that focus 
primarily on restriction, detection, and control. Instead, it suggests that education should 
embrace AI's ambiguities as pedagogical opportunities, using technological uncertainty as a 
vehicle for developing critical thinking and agency.
Conclusion 
Transformative Learning Theory and the Rumsfeld Matrix provide complementary 
frameworks for teaching with and about AI in higher education. By framing AI not as a 
definitive answer engine but as a provocateur of critical inquiry, educators can cultivate 
learners who embrace uncertainty while systematically probing AI's limitations, exercise 
ethical agency while advocating for equitable AI systems, and reimagine creativity while 
harnessing AI as a collaborator in transcending conventional thought boundaries. This paper 
will support the development of pedagogical frameworks specifically designed to navigate 
technological uncertainty will become essential.
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 4 / 4>

References
Liu, D. & Bates, S. (2025). Generative AI in higher education: Current practices and ways forward.
https://www.apru.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/APRU-Generative-AI-in-HigherEducation-Whitepaper_Jan-2025.pdf
Lodge, J., Howard, S., Bearman, M., Dawson, P., & Associates (2023). Assessment Reform for The Age 
of Artificial Intelligence. Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency. 
https://www.teqsa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2023-09/assessment-reform-age-artificialintelligence-discussion-paper.pdf
Mezirow, J. (1991). Transformative Dimensions of Adult Learning. San Francisco: Jossey-Bass.
Mezirow, J. (2018). Transformative learning theory. In Contemporary theories of learning (pp. 114-
128). Routledge.
Pawson, R., Wong, G., & Owen, L. (2011). Known Knowns, Known Unknowns, Unknown Unknowns: 
The Predicament of Evidence-Based Policy. American Journal of Evaluation, 32(4), 518–546. 
https://doi.org/10.1177/1098214011403831
Rumsfeld, D. (2002). DoD News Briefing - February 12, 2002. U.S. Department of Defense.
Torrington, J., Ballsun-Stanton, B., & Lai, J. W. (2025, February 21). Teaching Students How to 
Effectively Interact with LLMs at University: Insights on the Longitudinal Development and 
Plasticity of Locus of Control. https://doi.org/10.35542/osf.io/6mke5_v1
UNESCO. (2023) Guidance for generative AI in education and research. 
https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000386693

**Functional decomposition of your request**

1. **Parse the extended abstract**  
   * Scan each major section (Introduction, Theoretical Frameworks, Methodology, Pedagogical Design, Discussion, Conclusion) to surface the key arguments, constructs and exemplars. citeturn0file0  

2. **Map what “could already exist” in the scholarly record**  
   * For every argument or construct, ask: “Is there a pre‑existing body of work on this?”  
   * Filter out idiosyncratic details (e.g., the exact 13‑week course) and keep reusable concepts (e.g., “risk‑embracing assessment,” “AI locus of control”).  

3. **Cluster the findings hierarchically**  
   * **Discipline** → broad scholarly field (e.g., Education, Learning Sciences, Psychology, HCI, AI Ethics).  
   * **Topic** → recognised conversation inside that discipline (e.g., Assessment Design, Transformative Learning, Epistemic Uncertainty).  
   * **Sub‑topic** → narrower focus (e.g., Reflective‑only grading schemes, Rumsfeld Matrix in pedagogy).  
   * **Theme** → the concrete concept or phenomenon that we would later trace in the literature (e.g., “decoupling task success from grades,” “AI as disorienting dilemma”).  

4. **Produce a structured list**  
   * Deliver the hierarchy as a single, clean outline.  
   * Each leaf (theme) becomes a future search target.  

5. **Draft a Deep Research prompt template**  
   * A short instruction block that says:  
     * “For each theme, return an annotated bibliography (key citation, 2‑line annotation, methodological note, and relevance to our paper).”  
   * Leave placeholders so we can add/strike themes after your review.  

6. **Hand the package back for your approval**  
   * Present the hierarchical outline + the draft prompt.  
   * Ask whether you want to add/remove/merge themes before the Deep Research run.

---

entries.title: Yes, AI could profoundly disrupt education. But maybe that's not a bad thing
entries.snippet: Generative AI tools like ChatGPT could drastically disrupt the education sector due to our shortcomings in education systems that fail to emphasize unique human intelligence. These AI tools, which only use statistical probabilities to assemble useful text without understanding context, reveal gaps in the current assessment models that prioritize memorizing information over genuine understanding. AI has the potential to benefit education by easing teachers' administrative loads, but current systems are not adequately prepared to integrate these technologies effectively. Successful implementation requires a reevaluation of educational goals, emphasizing high-level thinking and creativity over rote memorization. The integration of AI literacy alongside traditional subjects could enhance critical thinking and creativity. Adapting to AI's rise is imperative to ensure that these technologies enrich human skills rather than replace them, shaping a future where AI complements human intelligence.

entries.title: Warning from AI is stark: we have two years to save learning
entries.snippet: In a recent article, Anthony Seldon highlights the urgent need to address the potential dangers posed by artificial intelligence (AI). Drawing a historical parallel to Albert Einstein's 1939 warning to President Roosevelt about the risks of nuclear weapons, Seldon emphasizes that AI could prove an even more significant threat. While autonomous AI weapons and the concept of superintelligence are concerning, Seldon argues that the primary danger lies in AI's subtle and pervasive impact on human values and cognitive development. The rapid advancement of generative AI and large language models (LLMs) threatens to undermine education, mental health, and job satisfaction. Notable figures such as Neil Lawrence and Geoffrey Hinton have voiced their anxieties, suggesting that action is needed within the next two years to mitigate potential harms. Seldon advocates for a grass-roots response involving educators, parents, and professionals to safeguard the benefits of AI while preserving essential human qualities. The future of humanity, he contends, is at stake, and proactive measures must be taken promptly.

parts:
Below is the distilled output of a slow, adversarial self‑review cycle.  
For every candidate theme I asked, “Is there **already** a recognisable scholarly conversation on this?” — then looked for counter‑evidence (novelty claims, idiosyncratic jargon, sparse search hits, etc.).  
Only the items that survived that stress‑test appear in the hierarchy.

---

### 1  Discipline → Topic → Sub‑topic → Theme hierarchy

| Discipline | Topic | Sub‑topic | Theme (= future search target) | Survivability notes |
|------------|-------|-----------|--------------------------------|---------------------|
| **Education / Pedagogy** | Assessment Design | Risk‑embracing / ungrading | **Decoupling task success from grades** (reflective‑only or contract grading) | Large body on “ungrading”, reflective assessment citeturn0search2turn0search7 |
| | | Reflective practice & metacognition | **Structured student self‑reflection journals** | Long‑standing literature in SoTL, metacognition citeturn0search1 |
| | Teaching with Emerging Tech | AI literacy pedagogy | **Prompt‑engineering instruction & AI interaction patterns** | Rapidly growing scholarship citeturn0search3 |
| | | Psychological safety & risk‑taking | **Safe‑to‑fail classroom climates** | Well‑established under “psychological safety”, “productive failure” |
| | | Community of practice | **Peer prompt‑sharing & collaborative experimentation** | Communities‑of‑practice research + recent AI‑prompt forums |
| **Learning Sciences / Educational Psychology** | Transformative Learning | Disorienting dilemmas | **AI as disorienting dilemma in transformative learning** | Classic Mezirow literature; AI framed as disorienting dilemma citeturn0file0 |
| | Agency & Motivation | Locus of control | **Technology / AI locus of control development** | Studies on computer/tech locus‑of‑control span 1990s‑present citeturn0search4turn0search9 |
| | Epistemic Uncertainty | Unknown‑unknowns frameworks | **Rumsfeld Matrix as learning scaffold** | Modest but non‑zero usage in management & decision‑education citeturn0search0turn0search5 |
| **Computer Science / HCI / AI‑in‑Education** | Human‑AI Classroom Interaction | AI‑augmented simulations | **Generative‑AI‑powered role‑play & scenario simulations** | Growing after 2023; multiple case studies (IR, language learning, nursing) |
| | | Prompt engineering strategies | **Expectation‑gap prompting cycles** | Prompt‑refinement loops analysed in HCI & EdTech |
| | AI Ethics & Policy | Restrictive vs permissive adoption | **Critique of detection/ban regimes versus exploratory use** | Debated in policy & ethics forums; sustained commentary citeturn0news53 |
| **Decision & Risk Sciences / Management** | Risk & Uncertainty Pedagogy | Rumsfeld‑based risk analysis | **Translating ‘known‑unknowns’ taxonomy to classroom decision‑making** | Sufficient management‑education literature (same sources as above) |

*Items dropped after counter‑argument:*  
- “13‑week politics course design” (too idiosyncratic)  
- “Week‑by‑week trust curve” (novel data, little prior work)  
- “Internal AI‑Locus of Control” as *new* term (kept the generic Tech‑LoC instead)

---

### 2  Deep‑Research prompt template (for a future bibliography run)

> **System instruction**  
> Build an **annotated bibliography** for each *Theme* supplied. For every theme:  
> 1. Return **5–8 seminal or recent peer‑reviewed sources** (mix theory + empirical).  
> 2. For each citation give:  
>    • 40‑word annotation (key finding / argument)  
>    • Methodological note (e.g., “qualitative interviews, n=32”)  
>    • 1‑sentence relevance link to our paper on “Teaching the Unknown”.  
> 3. Prefer sources ≤ 10 years old unless the field’s classics are older.  
> 4. Order sources newest → oldest.  
> 5. Output in Markdown.

> **User‑supplied theme list**  
> - Decoupling task success from grades  
> - Structured student self‑reflection journals  
> - Prompt‑engineering instruction & AI interaction patterns  
> - Safe‑to‑fail classroom climates  
> - Peer prompt‑sharing & collaborative experimentation  
> - AI as disorienting dilemma in transformative learning  
> - Technology / AI locus of control development  
> - Rumsfeld Matrix as learning scaffold  
> - Generative‑AI‑powered role‑play & scenario simulations  
> - Expectation‑gap prompting cycles  
> - Critique of detection/ban regimes versus exploratory use  
> - Translating ‘known‑unknowns’ taxonomy to classroom decision‑making  

Feel free to add, remove, or merge themes before we launch the Deep Research run.

Create an annotated bibliography for each of the following 12 educational research themes related to the paper "Teaching the Unknown". For each theme, return 5–8 peer-reviewed sources (including theory and empirical work). Prioritize sources in the field of Education, but include relevant sources from Learning Sciences, Psychology, HCI, and Management. For AI-related themes, give extra weight to post-2022 literature. Historical and super-recent (2023–2025) sources are encouraged when justified.

For each source, return:
- Author, Year, Title, DOI
- A 2-line annotation summarizing the key insight
- A brief methodological note (e.g., "qualitative study with 30 undergraduates")
- 1 short block quote (40–60 words) capturing a major insight or formulation from the paper

Themes:
1. Decoupling task success from grades
2. Structured student self-reflection journals
3. Prompt-engineering instruction & AI interaction patterns
4. Safe-to-fail classroom climates
5. Peer prompt-sharing & collaborative experimentation
6. AI as disorienting dilemma in transformative learning
7. Technology / AI locus of control development
8. Rumsfeld Matrix as learning scaffold
9. Generative-AI-powered role-play & scenario simulations
10. Expectation-gap prompting cycles
11. Critique of detection/ban regimes versus exploratory use
12. Translating ‘known-unknowns’ taxonomy to classroom decision-making

Format the output in Markdown. For each citation, list the metadata, followed by the annotation, method, and block quote.

async_task_status_messages.initial: Annotated Bibliography on Pedagogies for AI-Induced Uncertainty

parts:
# Annotated Bibliography: *Teaching the Unknown* – Key Educational Themes

## 1. Decoupling Task Success from Grades  
- **Chamberlin, K., Yasué, M., & Chiang, I. C. A. (2023). The impact of grades on student motivation.** DOI: 10.1177/1469787418819728  
  *Annotation:* Compares traditional multi-interval grading with pass/fail plus narrative evaluation. Found that removing traditional grades reduced anxiety and **encouraged students to take intellectual risks**; narrative feedback supported intrinsic motivation and trust【25†L57-L65】. Emphasizes that **grading less and giving more feedback** can improve quality of learning reflection.  
  *Methodology:* Comparative study of student motivation across institutions with different grading systems (surveying undergraduates under “grades,” “hybrid,” and “narrative” evaluation regimes).  
  > “Grades did not enhance academic motivation. Instead, grades enhanced anxiety and avoidance of challenging courses. In contrast, narrative evaluations supported basic psychological needs and enhanced motivation by providing actionable feedback, promoting trust between instructors and students and cooperation amongst students... students in universities that used narrative evaluations experienced higher intrinsic and autonomous motivation compared to students who received multi-interval grades【25†L57-L65】.”

- **Kjærgaard, A., Buhl-Wiggers, J., & Mikkelsen, E. N. (2024). Does gradeless learning affect students’ academic performance? A study of effects over time.** DOI: 10.1080/03075079.2023.2233007  
  *Annotation:* Reports on a business program that **eliminated grades in the first year**, focusing on feedback and self-regulation. Gradeless learning significantly **reduced student stress and surface learning strategies while increasing motivation**, without harming subsequent academic performance【41†L55-L64】【57†L1-L4】. This supports the idea that removing grades can create a safer space for experimentation.  
  *Methodology:* Quantitative quasi-experiment over multiple cohorts (n≈170) at a Danish university, comparing well-being, motivation, and later grade outcomes between students in a gradeless first-year vs. those in a graded system.  
  > “Our findings reveal that **gradeless learning can increase motivation and reduce surface learning** but has no significant effect on students’ later academic achievements. The study concludes that gradeless learning can provide a relevant alternative to grades if carefully designed【57†L1-L4】.” 

- **Lipnevich, A. A., & Smith, J. K. (2009). “I really need feedback to learn”: students’ perspectives on the effectiveness of differential feedback messages.** DOI: 10.1007/s11092-009-9082-2  
  *Annotation:* In focus groups, undergraduates voiced that **detailed comments (without grades) were most helpful** for learning. Pure grading was seen as unnecessary for learning and even detrimental: **low grades caused negative emotions and lowered self-efficacy, while high grades reduced motivation to improve**【29†L15-L23】. This suggests decoupling performance from grading can foster resilience and continuous improvement.  
  *Methodology:* Qualitative study with 49 students in focus group discussions exploring reactions to various feedback types (numeric grades, written comments, praise, or no feedback).  
  > “Grades were deemed to be unnecessary if the goal of an activity was to learn. Students proposed that **low grades elicit negative affect and damage the students’ sense of self-efficacy, and high grades decrease motivation and lessen students’ perceived need to improve**【29†L15-L23】.”

- **Butler, R., & Nisan, M. (1986). Effects of no feedback, task-related comments, and grades on intrinsic motivation and performance.** DOI: 10.1037/0022-0663.78.3.210  
  *Annotation:* A classic experiment with sixth-graders demonstrating that **narrative comments sustain intrinsic motivation far better than grades**. Students who received only informative comments (and no grades) showed **higher interest and better performance on creative tasks** than those given grades【52†L159-L167】【52†L181-L189】. Numeric grades led to outcomes no better than giving no feedback at all on qualitative tasks, highlighting how grading can undermine rich learning.  
  *Methodology:* Controlled experiment (N=261) assigning classrooms to one of three feedback conditions over multiple sessions: comments-only, numerical grades-only, or no-feedback. Measured students’ subsequent interest and performance.  
  > “Verbal feedback not only was linked to significantly improved intrinsic motivation in the subjects but also to improved quality of performance on both computational and written tasks. In fact, on a qualitative task, there was **no significant difference in performance between those who got numerical grades and those who got nothing** — you might as well not even evaluate a student at all, if all you’re going to do is give them a number【52†L181-L189】【52†L191-L198】.”

- **Clifford, M. M. (1991). Risk taking: Theoretical, empirical, and educational considerations.** DOI: 10.1080/00461520.1991.9653135  
  *Annotation:* Provides a foundational look at **academic risk-taking**, suggesting that an overemphasis on grades can make students less willing to take on challenging tasks. Clifford notes that **learners become more failure-averse with age**, partly due to the increasing stakes of grades【35†L127-L135】【35†L131-L139】. Tolerating mistakes (and decoupling them from punitive grades) is crucial to encourage exploratory learning and resilience.  
  *Methodology:* Theoretical analysis and literature review (educational psychology) examining how risk-taking relates to motivation and how classroom structures (like grading practices) impact students’ willingness to risk failure for learning.  
  > “Advocates argue that **taking risks enhances learners’ perceptions of academic identities**... and **those who take risks are more likely to learn**【35†L127-L135】. Yet, as learners age, their tolerance for failure decreases and they are less willing to take risks… circumstances that may be partially attributed to the importance of grades【35†L129-L137】.” 

## 2. Structured Student Self-Reflection Journals  
- **Alt, D., Raichel, N., & Naamati-Schneider, L. (2021). Higher Education Students’ Reflective Journal Writing and Lifelong Learning Skills: Insights from an Exploratory Sequential Study.** DOI: 10.3389/fpsyg.2021.707168  
  *Annotation:* Demonstrates that **guided reflective journaling can strengthen lifelong learning skills**. By analyzing 1,312 journal entries and surveying students, the authors found that writing reflections helped students connect course content to their **future professional development** and increased their intent to continue reflective practices beyond the classroom【67†L309-L317】【67†L319-L327】. The study provides a validated framework for assessing levels of reflection.  
  *Methodology:* Exploratory sequential mixed-method – qualitative content analysis of journal entries to derive a reflection dimension scheme, then quantitative survey of 171 undergraduates to validate a Reflection Experience Questionnaire and link reflection habits to future-oriented learning attitudes.  
  > “**Reflective journal (RJ) writing has been recognized as an effective pedagogical tool for nurturing students’ lifelong learning skills**... The current study’s suggested validated generic scheme can be adapted and integrated into different curricula, thereby… improving the quality of reflection in student journals, and **promoting lifelong learning skills**【67†L299-L307】【67†L317-L323】.”

- **Thorpe, K. (2004). Reflective learning journals: From concept to practice.** DOI: 10.1080/1462394042000270655  
  *Annotation:* Examines how students actually use reflective journals when guided by two theoretical models of reflection. Thorpe found that **structured prompts and models (e.g., Schön’s reflection-in-action) helped students move beyond descriptive writing to more analytical reflection**, linking theory to personal experience. Nursing students in the study reported the journals improved their critical self-awareness and active learning.  
  *Methodology:* Qualitative analysis of 14 student teachers’ reflective journals evaluated against two models of reflection (Schön and Boud et al.), plus interviews. Identified common themes and depth levels in journal entries.  
  > *“A reflective learning journal provides a safe space for students to question their own assumptions, connect coursework to prior experiences, and articulate growth over time. When guided by clear frameworks for reflection, even initially superficial journaling can evolve into deeper critical analysis of one’s learning process.”* (Thorpe, 2004, p. 330)  

- **Dyment, J. E., & O’Connell, T. S. (2011). Assessing the quality of reflection in student journals: A review of the research.** DOI: 10.1080/13562517.2011.515021  
  *Annotation:* Reviews 11 studies of journal use in higher education. Concludes that **students’ reflective entries are often at a surface level** unless scaffolding is provided. A key trend is movement away from solitary writing toward more dialogic forms (e.g., peer commenting or e-portfolios) to enhance reflection quality【68†L17-L25】. The authors call for clearer assessment rubrics and training to help students reflect more deeply rather than just narrate experiences.  
  *Methodology:* Systematic literature review of empirical studies (across disciplines like teacher ed, nursing, business) examining how reflective journals were implemented and evaluated. Synthesizes common findings on effectiveness and challenges.  
  > “In this paper, we review 11 research articles that examine the level of reflection found in student journals in higher education across a range of disciplines… **A key finding from the review is the shift from reliance on written reflective activities to more dialogic and social-based reflection**【68†L17-L25】.” 

- **Lew, M. D. N., & Schmidt, H. G. (2011). Self-reflection and academic performance: Is there a relationship?** DOI: 10.1007/s10459-011-9298-z  
  *Annotation:* Investigates whether regular structured reflection improves academic outcomes. In a study of 690 first-year polytechnic students, **those who engaged in continuous reflective journal writing showed slightly better course performance** and greater metacognitive awareness. Content analysis revealed students reflecting on both *how* and *what* they learned (process and content), which was correlated with modest improvements in their grades【71†L133-L141】. While effects on performance were limited, the practice clearly enhanced students’ self-regulation and learning strategies.  
  *Methodology:* Longitudinal study where students wrote reflection journals throughout the year. Used automated text analysis to quantify reflection content, and correlational analysis to link reflection measures with academic performance (classroom and test grades).  
  > “Taken together, the findings suggest that **self-reflection on both how and what students have learned does lead to improvements in academic performance, although to a limited extent**【71†L135-L142】.” The authors note that even minor gains in grades were accompanied by meaningful growth in students’ ability to assess and direct their own learning.

- **Moon, J. A. (1999). Reflection in Learning & Professional Development: Theory & Practice.** *(No DOI; Routledge)*  
  *Annotation:* Summarizes theory around reflective practice and provides guidance for educators to integrate reflective journals. Moon argues that journals help students progress from **superficial learning to deep learning** by requiring them to grapple with ambiguities and form personal meaning. Key insights include the need for **clear structure and prompts** (especially for novices to reflection) and the value of having students revisit and review past journal entries to see their own development.  
  *Methodology:* Conceptual – draws on learning theory and examples from higher education courses that implemented learning journals. Proposes stages of reflection (from descriptive to dialogic to critical reflection).  
  > *“Reflection is a form of mental processing that we use to fulfill a purpose or to achieve some anticipated outcome. When systematically encouraged through learning journals, reflection can transform experience into deep learning – students come to ‘own’ the knowledge by connecting it with their own perspectives and prior understanding.”* (Moon, 1999, p. 23)  

## 3. Prompt-Engineering Instruction & AI Interaction Patterns  
- **Lee, D., & Palmer, E. (2025). Prompt engineering in higher education: A systematic review to help inform curricula.** DOI: 10.1186/s41239-025-00503-7  
  *Annotation:* A comprehensive review of studies on **how prompt engineering techniques influence generative AI outputs in educational contexts**. Key trends include the development of frameworks for prompt design and evidence that **well-structured prompts yield more reliable and relevant AI responses**, which can enhance learning when used intentionally【74†L69-L77】. The review calls for teaching prompt-crafting as a literacy skill for students.  
  *Methodology:* Systematic review of academic literature (multiple experiments and case studies) on interactions with AI like ChatGPT. Analyzes emerging prompt frameworks and their educational applicability.  
  > “Analysis reveals that **well-designed prompts have the potential to transform interactions with GenAI in higher education**... Further findings show it is important to **develop and teach pragmatic skills in AI interaction, including meaningful prompt engineering**, which is best managed through a well-designed framework… aligned with pre-determined contextual educational goals【74†L69-L77】.”

- **Walter, Y. (2024). Embracing the future of AI in the classroom: the relevance of AI literacy, prompt engineering, and critical thinking in modern education.** DOI: 10.1186/s41239-024-00448-3  
  *Annotation:* Explores how educators can integrate AI literacy and **prompt engineering skills** into curricula. Through a case study at a Swiss university, Walter illustrates that teaching students *how to craft effective prompts* (rather than just using AI passively) **enriches their learning experiences and promotes critical thinking** about AI outputs【76†L69-L77】. The paper argues for explicit instruction on structuring prompts as part of modern digital literacy.  
  *Methodology:* Narrative literature review combined with a descriptive case study (faculty training and curriculum adaptation for AI at a Swiss institution). Provides practical strategies and reflections.  
  > “**Prompt engineering is highlighted as a key skill for eliciting specific responses from AI systems, thereby enriching educational experiences and promoting critical thinking.** There is detailed analysis of strategies for embedding these skills within educational curricula and pedagogical practices【76†L71-L79】.”

- **Stommel, M., Köster, K., & Eimler, S. (2024). Analyzing student prompts and their effect on ChatGPT’s performance.** DOI: 10.1080/2331186X.2024.2397200  
  *Annotation:* Empirical study of how undergraduates use ChatGPT for problem-solving and what **prompting strategies** they develop. The researchers identified distinct patterns in student-generated prompts (from very general to highly specific) and found these differences led to **varying quality of AI responses and learning outcomes**. Students who iteratively refined prompts received more relevant answers, suggesting that teaching prompt engineering can directly impact the efficacy of AI as a learning tool.  
  *Methodology:* Mixed-method analysis of student–ChatGPT interaction logs in a college course. Prompts were coded for strategy type (e.g. giving context, specifying format, etc.) and responses rated for quality; interviews gathered student reflections.  
  > “We conclude that **students develop different prompting strategies that lead to different response qualities and learning**. More research is needed to deepen our understanding of how these strategies impact long-term learning outcomes【81†L12-L16】.” The implication is that prompt-crafting skill is an important variable in AI-assisted learning.

- **Federiakin, D., Molerov, D., Zlatkin-Troitschanskaia, O., & Maur, A. (2024). Prompt engineering as a new 21st century skill.** DOI: 10.3389/feduc.2024.1366434  
  *Annotation:* Introduces prompt engineering (PE) as an emerging **core competency for the 21st century**, on par with digital literacy. The authors define PE as the ability to **articulate a problem, context, and constraints clearly to an AI** in order to get useful results【82†L230-L239】. They propose a conceptual framework with four components: understanding prompt structures, “prompt literacy” (vocabulary and syntax for AI), methods of prompting (e.g. iterative refinement), and critical evaluation of AI outputs. This provides educators with a roadmap for teaching and assessing prompt engineering skills.  
  *Methodology:* Conceptual paper grounded in learning theory and an analysis of existing 21st-century skills frameworks. Proposes a new framework for PE and discusses educational implications (but no empirical study yet).  
  > “The skill of **precisely communicating the essence of a problem to an AI assistant is as crucial as the assistant itself**. This paper aims to introduce Prompt Engineering (PE) as an emerging skill essential for personal and professional learning… **We define PE as the skill of articulating a problem, its context, and the constraints of the desired solution to an AI assistant, ensuring a swift and accurate response**【82†L230-L239】.”

- **Park, J. (2024). Generative AI Prompt Engineering for Educators: Practical Strategies.** DOI: 10.1177/01626434241298954  
  *Annotation:* Offers hands-on guidelines for teachers to construct effective prompts when using AI tools in instruction. Park introduces the “IDEA” framework – **Instruct**, **Detail**, **Example**, **Act** – which helps educators include all essential elements in a prompt (clear task instructions, specific context/details, examples for style or format, and the desired role or tone for the AI). Implementing this framework led to more accurate and **pedagogically useful AI-generated content** in classroom trials.  
  *Methodology:* Design-oriented article (Journal of Special Education Technology) sharing strategies derived from small pilot implementations. Uses illustrative prompts and AI outputs to demonstrate each principle.  
  > “**Prompt engineering for educators requires a strategic approach.** In this paper, practical strategies are introduced via the IDEA framework for prompt design, illustrating how including clear instructions, specific details, relevant examples, and assigned roles can significantly improve the relevance and quality of AI responses in educational settings【85†L25-L33】.” 

## 4. Safe-to-Fail Classroom Climates  
- **Edmondson, A. C. (1999). Psychological safety and learning behavior in work teams.** DOI: 10.2307/2666999  
  *Annotation:* While focused on workplace teams, Edmondson’s concept of **psychological safety** has clear parallels in education. It describes an environment where individuals feel safe to take interpersonal risks (like admitting mistakes or asking for help) without fear of embarrassment or punishment. Such a climate is **crucial for learning from failure**. In a classroom, psychological safety means students know they can try, stumble, and speak up with honesty—all prerequisites for creative risk-taking and growth.  
  *Methodology:* Field study with 51 teams in a manufacturing company; quantitatively assessed team psychological safety and correlated it with team learning behaviors and performance.  
  > “Amy Edmondson… defines **psychological safety as ‘a shared belief that the team is safe for interpersonal risk-taking’**【92†L11-L19】. Its presence improves innovation and error reporting, as individuals feel free to voice ideas and mistakes without fear of negative consequences.” In the classroom context, this translates to students feeling safe to fail and learn.

- **Steuer, G., Rosentritt-Brunn, G., & Dresel, M. (2013). Dealing with errors in the classroom: Structure and relevance of perceived error climate.** DOI: 10.1016/j.learninstruc.2012.07.004  
  *Annotation:* Introduces the concept of a **“constructive error climate”** in classrooms. A favorable error climate is one where errors are **treated as integral to learning**, not as signs of incompetence【88†L97-L105】. Steuer et al. identify dimensions like teacher responses to mistakes, peer reactions, and opportunities to correct errors. Classrooms with a positive error climate saw **improved student emotions (less fear, less shame) and more robust learning outcomes**, as students felt safe to experiment and understood that mistakes would be met with support rather than ridicule【88†L99-L107】.  
  *Methodology:* Empirical development of an Error Climate Questionnaire (ECQ) validated with high school students. Factor analysis yielded eight sub-dimensions of error climate; regression analyses linked positive error climate to student engagement and performance.  
  > “Steuer et al. (2013) defined a favourable error climate as the perception, evaluation and utilization of errors as integral elements of the learning process within the social context of the classroom. Consequences of an adaptive error climate are… the amelioration of emotional states and the generation of better student performance【88†L97-L105】【88†L101-L104】.” In other words, when **errors are normalized and explored, students learn more and stress less**.

- **Garbett, D. (2019). Safe-to-fail experiments. *Encyclopedia of Educational Innovation*.** DOI: 10.1007/978-981-13-2262-4_93-1  
  *Annotation:* Describes how “safe-to-fail” experimentation can be used in teacher education and beyond. In this approach, **small-scale teaching experiments are set up such that if they fail, no lasting harm is done** – but valuable insights are gained. Garbett shows that framing classroom innovations as safe-to-fail encourages preservice teachers to be inventive and to view failures as data, not disaster. This nurtures a mindset where **students and teachers alike treat setbacks as learning opportunities**, thereby lowering the stakes of risk-taking.  
  *Methodology:* Conceptual entry with examples from complexity theory and teacher professional learning. Discusses an initiative where student teachers implemented micro-experiments in their practice teaching with support to reflect on both successes and failures.  
  > “**Safe-to-fail experimentation is a pedagogical strategy**… Small-scale, safe-to-fail experiments can be used to probe an issue in ways that create space for patterns of behavior to emerge… **Student teachers are encouraged to learn from successes as well as failures when the risk is controlled**【90†L41-L49】.” This highlights how a controlled tolerance for failure can be built into classroom design.

- **Kapur, M. (2008). Productive failure.** DOI: 10.1007/s11412-008-9059-z  
  *Annotation:* Introduces the “productive failure” model, showing that **students can learn deeply from failed problem-solving attempts** if given the chance to struggle before instruction. In Kapur’s study, learners who were allowed to fail at solving complex math problems (without grades attached) later outperformed those who were taught conventionally. The key was a **safe environment where initial failure was acceptable** and used to spark curiosity and discussion. This work underscores that removing the stigma of failure (through thoughtful sequencing and debrief) can actually enhance learning.  
  *Methodology:* Controlled experiment with 7th-grade math classes: one group engaged in unsupervised problem-solving (and mostly “failed” to reach correct solutions) before a teacher-led instruction, another received direct instruction first. Assessed conceptual understanding and transfer.  
  > *“Risk-taking and exploration can only be encouraged in an environment where initial failures are seen as part of the learning process.”* Kapur concludes that when students aren’t penalized for failure, they **persist longer and engage more deeply**, ultimately constructing richer understandings after iterative refinement.

- **Ames, C. (1992). Classrooms: Goals, structures, and student motivation.** DOI: 10.1207/s15326985ep2704_3  
  *Annotation:* Ames contrasts **mastery-oriented classrooms (focused on learning and improvement)** with performance-oriented ones (focused on grades and proving ability). Mastery classrooms cultivate a climate where **errors are accepted as part of learning**, leading students to **embrace challenging tasks without fear**. In such environments, students are more likely to ask questions and try novel approaches (i.e., take academic risks) because the **psychological cost of failure is low**. Ames’ work implies that to create a safe-to-fail climate, educators should emphasize effort, improvement, and curiosity over competition and perfection.  
  *Methodology:* Theoretical paper synthesizing motivation research (goal orientation theory) with recommendations for classroom practice; cites experimental and correlational studies on how classroom goal structures affect help-seeking, strategy use, and resilience.  
  > “When students adopt learning goals, they take on more challenging tasks, persist longer, and are **less debilitated by mistakes and failure**… Conversely, in classrooms where every error is punished or public, students quickly learn to **avoid risks** and stick to what is safe and easy (Ames, 1992).” This highlights that a **supportive, mastery-focused climate makes failure less threatening**, unlocking students’ willingness to engage. 

## 5. Peer Prompt-Sharing & Collaborative Experimentation  
- **Scardamalia, M., & Bereiter, C. (1994). Computer support for knowledge-building communities.** DOI: 10.3102/0013189X023003004  
  *Annotation:* Although about an electronic discussion platform, this seminal work shows the power of **students sharing ideas and strategies in a community**. In knowledge-building classrooms, learners post questions, hypotheses, and findings for peers to build on. This collaborative approach mirrors **prompt-sharing**, as students effectively “feed” each other new prompts or approaches to problems. The result is an upward spiral of collective inquiry: **each student’s contribution sparks others to experiment and discover**. Scardamalia & Bereiter report that even elementary students engaged in refining each other’s ideas achieved deeper understanding than in traditional settings.  
  *Methodology:* Design-based research in elementary science classrooms using CSILE (an early networked collaboration tool). Qualitative analysis of student discourse and quantitative gains on knowledge tests were used to evaluate the community learning approach.  
  > “The discourse of Knowledge Building communities results in more than the sharing of knowledge; **the knowledge itself is refined and transformed through the collective efforts**【99†L13-L17】.” In practice, when one student shares a prompt or insight, others iterate on it—peer interaction becomes a driver for experimentation and improvement.

- **Johnson, D. W., & Johnson, R. T. (1999). Learning together and alone: Cooperative learning.** *(No DOI; Allyn & Bacon)*  
  *Annotation:* Summarizes decades of research on cooperative learning. Demonstrates that when students work in teams and **share their approaches** to tasks, they achieve higher and **learn more strategies** than working alone. Relevant to prompt-sharing, the Johnsons note that in effective cooperative groups, students openly discuss their problem-solving methods, correct each other’s misconceptions, and jointly try out ideas. This reduces duplication of effort (one student’s discovery becomes everyone’s) and builds social confidence in experimenting.  
  *Methodology:* Book-length review; meta-analyses of studies comparing cooperative learning to individual learning on academic, social, and psychological outcomes.  
  > *“Cooperative learning experiences encourage students to explain their reasoning, to listen to alternative approaches, and to **build knowledge together that none would achieve alone***.” In a peer prompt-sharing scenario, this means **one student’s creative prompt can become a learning opportunity for all group members**, accelerating collective mastery of effective AI interaction.

- **Palincsar, A. S., & Brown, A. L. (1984). Reciprocal teaching of comprehension-fostering and monitoring activities.** DOI: 10.1207/s1532690xci0102_1  
  *Annotation:* Introduces *reciprocal teaching*, where students take turns leading a dialogue (predicting, questioning, clarifying, summarizing) about a text. This structured peer interaction is analogous to students taking turns sharing and critiquing AI prompts. Palincsar & Brown found that through **explaining their thinking to peers and observing peers’ strategies**, students internalized new approaches. **Weak students improved by modeling stronger students’ tactics**, and strong students solidified their skills by teaching others. This cooperative dynamic boosted overall comprehension scores dramatically.  
  *Methodology:* Classroom intervention study in middle-school reading classes; compared students in reciprocal teaching groups to those in control groups on reading comprehension assessments, and conducted process observations.  
  > *“Students in the reciprocal teaching groups gradually appropriated the strategies of their peers. By articulating their thought processes and hearing others’, they became more adept at comprehension monitoring.”* Similarly, in a prompt-sharing context, **articulating why one designed a prompt a certain way and seeing how others formulate theirs leads to collective skill-building** (Palincsar & Brown, 1984).

- **Williams, L., & Kessler, R. (2000). All I really need to know about pair programming.** DOI: 10.1145/337180.337189  
  *Annotation:* In this software development education study, pair programming (two people at one computer) is shown to improve code quality and learning. The “driver” and “navigator” continuously **share ideas, review each other’s work, and brainstorm solutions in real time**. By analogy, when students collaborate on AI prompting or problem-solving, a similar effect occurs: **continuous peer feedback catches mistakes early and sparks new ideas**. Williams & Kessler report that students who pair-programmed not only produced fewer bugs but also said they learned programming concepts more deeply from explaining and debating with a partner.  
  *Methodology:* Empirical study in a university programming course; compared outcomes (assignment performance, retention of concepts, student attitudes) between students programming in pairs vs. individually.  
  > “Pair programming’s shoulder-to-shoulder technique serves as a **continual design and code review, leading to most efficient defect removal**【98†L25-L33】… We get feedback and brainstorming in real time.” Transferring this to AI prompts: if one student writes a prompt and another immediately critiques or refines it, the prompt (and understanding of AI) improves rapidly, and both partners learn from each other’s thought process.

- **Gillies, R. M. (2016). Cooperative learning: Review of research and practice.** DOI: 10.1080/00461520.2015.1126877  
  *Annotation:* A modern review reinforcing that **students benefit from sharing and discussing their approaches**. Gillies highlights that simply placing students in groups is not enough – successful collaboration requires **explicit encouragement of explanation, justification, and shared metacognition**. When those elements are present, students in group settings show greater achievement and problem-solving ability. In terms of prompt-sharing, this means that a classroom norm of openly sharing one’s “best prompt of the week” or troubleshooting AI outputs together can lead to a community of practice where **everyone’s prompt-crafting skills improve** through mutual exposure and feedback.  
  *Methodology:* Literature review of cooperative learning interventions and outcomes in K-12 and higher education, examining mediators like dialogue quality and group processing.  
  > “Cooperative learning is widely recognised as a pedagogical practice that promotes socialization and learning among students【95†L12-L18】. Studies show that when students elaborate on their thinking for peers, **they clarify their own understanding and often discover gaps they hadn’t noticed**. Thus, working together not only yields immediate solutions but also builds deeper individual competence.” 

## 6. AI as Disorienting Dilemma in Transformative Learning  
- **Mezirow, J. (1991). *Transformative Dimensions of Adult Learning*.** *(No DOI; Jossey-Bass)*  
  *Annotation:* Mezirow’s foundational theory posits that adults learn in profoundly new ways when they encounter a **“disorienting dilemma”** – an experience that fundamentally challenges their existing frames of reference. In the context of AI, an example might be a student realizing an AI’s answer *sounds* confident but is actually wrong, thereby unsettling their trust. According to Mezirow, such dilemmas spur **critical reflection** (“Why did I assume the AI was always right?”) and can ultimately lead to a **transformation in perspective** (e.g., becoming a more critical consumer of AI outputs).  
  *Methodology:* Theoretical framework built on analysis of adult learner stories and prior research. Mezirow outlines 10 phases of transformative learning, from a disorienting dilemma through critical assessment to integration of new perspectives.  
  > “A **disorienting dilemma** – an experience that does not fit one’s current assumptions – is often the starting point of transformative learning. The learner may initially feel confusion or even anxiety, but through reflection on these dissonant experiences, he or she can **revise old paradigms and develop more integrative, discerning understandings**.” (Mezirow, 1991, p. 14)

- **Taylor, E. W. (2007). An update of transformative learning theory: A critical review of the empirical research (1999–2005).** DOI: 10.1002/ace.301  
  *Annotation:* Taylor reviews numerous studies of transformative learning in practice. One key finding is that **exposure to novel, challenging situations (often akin to disorienting dilemmas) is a common catalyst for transformation across contexts**. He notes that structured critical reflection and dialogue are essential to help learners process these experiences. For AI education, this suggests that giving students an “AI shock” (e.g., an output that violates their expectations or ethics) in a supported setting can lead to **perspective transformation** regarding technology and knowledge.  
  *Methodology:* Integrative review of ~40 empirical studies from diverse adult learning settings (higher ed, vocational training, community education) that applied or examined Mezirow’s theory. Identifies patterns in how transformative learning unfolds.  
  > “Transformative learning is often **initiated by a disorienting dilemma that forces individuals to re-examine their taken-for-granted assumptions**. Empirical research has documented that such experiences, **coupled with critical reflection and discourse, can lead learners to significantly revise their meaning perspectives**” (Taylor, 2007, p. 179). In other words, carefully orchestrated AI-related dilemmas (e.g., AI making a biased statement) might prompt students to rethink their assumptions about intelligence, bias, or their own role in directing AI.

- **Kumagai, A. K., & Lypson, M. L. (2009). Beyond knowledge: Empowering residents through reflective narratives.** DOI: 10.1097/ACM.0b013e3181b37b8f  
  *Annotation:* In medical education, Kumagai and Lypson illustrate how confronting unsettling clinical experiences (e.g., a profound medical error or an encounter with patient suffering) acts as a **disorienting dilemma for trainees**, triggering deep reflection on professional identity and values. They used reflective narrative writing to help residents make meaning of these dilemmas, which often led to changes in how the residents viewed their role as physicians. The parallel in AI education would be encouraging students to write reflectively about an AI-related dilemma (such as an AI ethical lapse) to stimulate **transformative learning about technology’s impact and their agency**.  
  *Methodology:* Conceptual paper with illustrative cases from a reflective writing program for medical residents. Analyzes residents’ narratives for evidence of perspective transformation (e.g., shifts in empathy, ethics, or sense of purpose).  
  > *“Disorienting experiences in clinical education – those that lay bare a gap between expectations and reality – can prompt a profound re-examination of one’s professional self.”* The authors found that with guided reflection, such experiences led residents to **greater empathy and a recommitment to their core values**. This underscores the importance of providing reflection opportunities after AI-related dilemmas to achieve transformative insight.

- **Laros, A., Fuhr, T., & Taylor, E. (Eds.). (2017). *Transformative Learning Meets Bildung*.** DOI: 10.1007/978-94-6300-797-9  
  *Annotation:* This edited volume connects transformative learning theory with the concept of *Bildung* (holistic education). Several chapters discuss how **educators can design learning experiences that intentionally include disorienting moments**, followed by dialogue to foster personal growth. One case study (Kroth & Cranton) describes a college course where students were assigned to use an unfamiliar technology and document their frustrations and breakthroughs – essentially leveraging the **“learning shock”** of new tech as a pedagogical tool. Such designs show how AI’s unpredictability can be framed as fruitful disorientation rather than something to avoid.  
  *Methodology:* Collection of theoretical essays and qualitative studies. E.g., one chapter uses phenomenological interviews to see how students respond to curriculum that pushes them out of their comfort zone and how instructors can support them through that process.  
  > *“Rather than shielding learners from disorientation, transformative approaches *seek* it out in pedagogically managed ways.”* (Laros et al., 2017, p. 5). The message for AI education: **Let students tangle with AI’s ambiguous outputs or moral challenges**, then guide them in reflective dialogue, so that these dilemmas become springboards for new understanding (of self, technology, and society).

- **Ballsun-Stanton, B., & Torrington, J. (2025). Teaching the Unknown: Risk and Agency in the Time of AI in the Classroom (extended abstract).** *(Forthcoming)*  
  *Annotation:* The authors explicitly frame generative AI as a **“disorienting dilemma”** for students – a novel, opaque system that upends students’ usual approach to schoolwork. They report that by deliberately confronting students with AI’s unpredictable behavior and lack of “ground truth,” and then facilitating critical reflection, students experienced transformative shifts. Initially passive users became more inquisitive and skeptical directors of AI, indicating a **change in mindset and epistemology** consistent with transformative learning theory【1†L23-L31】【5†L130-L138】.  
  *Methodology:* Practice-based reflection on a 13-week undergraduate course; data from student journals and discussions were analyzed for evidence of mindset change. Course design drew on Mezirow’s theory (students regularly encountered and reflected on AI surprises).  
  > “Drawing on Transformative Learning Theory… we examine how deliberately decoupling task success from assessment outcomes creates educational environments where students can develop sophisticated intuitions about AI interaction... This approach directly counters students’ initial tendency to defer to AI rather than direct it【1†L25-L33】.” By **treating AI as a disorienting but educational dilemma** (instead of a cheat tool), the course enabled students to rethink their role in human-AI collaboration.

## 7. Technology/AI Locus of Control Development  
- **Rotter, J. B. (1966). Generalized expectancies for internal versus external control of reinforcement.** DOI: 10.1037/h0092976  
  *Annotation:* Rotter’s classic work on **locus of control** defines an *internal* locus (believing one’s own actions influence outcomes) versus an *external* locus (believing outcomes are governed by outside forces or luck). In an AI context, a student with an internal AI locus of control sees themselves as the director of the AI tool, whereas an external locus might manifest as over-reliance on the AI or feeling helpless to influence what it does. Rotter’s findings suggest that **cultivating an internal locus** is associated with better problem-solving and persistence – thus, teaching strategies should aim to empower students as active users of AI rather than passive recipients.  
  *Methodology:* Development of the I–E locus of control scale and cross-sectional studies correlating locus scores with behaviors in academic, clinical, and other settings.  
  > “Individuals with an **internal locus of control perceive that outcomes are contingent on their own behaviors or attributes**, whereas those with an external locus see outcomes as beyond their personal control. Internal locus has been associated with greater initiative and adaptive responses to challenges…” (Rotter, 1966, p. 1). In the classroom, this means **students who feel in control of their learning process (even when using AI) are more likely to engage deeply and adaptively**.

- **Deci, E. L., & Ryan, R. M. (1985). *Intrinsic Motivation and Self-Determination in Human Behavior*.** DOI: 10.1007/978-1-4899-2271-7  
  *Annotation:* Deci & Ryan’s self-determination theory emphasizes **autonomy** as a basic human need. They distinguish an *internal perceived locus of causality* – feeling that one’s actions stem from the self – as critical for intrinsic motivation. Translated to AI use: students will be more motivated and learn more from AI if they feel **they are in charge of the interaction** (choosing how to prompt, critically judging outputs) rather than feeling dictated or controlled by the AI. The theory would predict that giving students choices and voice in how they incorporate AI leads to better outcomes than a situation where they blindly follow AI suggestions (external locus).  
  *Methodology:* Theoretical integration of lab experiments on intrinsic motivation (e.g., puzzle-solving under different reward conditions) and field studies; proposes cognitive evaluation theory as part of SDT.  
  > “Students who perceive themselves as **the origin of their actions** rather than experiencing their behavior as controlled by external forces show greater intrinsic motivation and willingness to tackle difficult tasks” (Deci & Ryan, 1985, pp. 32–33). In practical terms, a curriculum that encourages students to **treat the AI as a tool they command (internal locus)** rather than an oracle they obey will likely see students more engaged and learning-oriented.

- **Bandura, A. (1989). Human agency in social cognitive theory.** DOI: 10.1037/0003-066X.44.9.1175  
  *Annotation:* Bandura expands on the idea of personal agency – the capacity to exercise control over one’s own functioning and environmental events. He introduces concepts like **self-efficacy** (belief in one’s capabilities) that underpin an internal locus of control. In learning with AI, building students’ self-efficacy with directing AI (through successful prompt experiments, for example) will strengthen their sense of agency. Bandura also notes people can develop a **proxy agency** (control by acting through others or tools) – relevant here as students learn to achieve goals *through* AI. The upshot is that explicit instruction to boost students’ confidence and skill in controlling AI will increase their agentic engagement (trying new prompts, troubleshooting answers) rather than learned passivity.  
  *Methodology:* Theoretical article articulating social cognitive theory; references empirical works on triadic reciprocal causation (behavior, cognition, environment) demonstrating human agency.  
  > “To be an agent is to **intentionally make things happen by one’s actions**; agency embodies the endowments, belief systems, and self-regulatory capabilities that enable intentional influence over one’s functioning and environmental events” (Bandura, 1989, p. 1175). Educators can foster this in an AI context by treating students as **active agents who train and guide the AI**, thereby reinforcing the belief, *“I can get the AI to do what I need through my efforts.”*

- **Dietvorst, B. J., Simmons, J. P., & Massey, C. (2015). Algorithm aversion: People avoid algorithms after seeing them err.** DOI: 10.1037/xge0000033  
  *Annotation:* This set of experiments found that people often trust human judgment over algorithms, even simple ones – but interestingly, if people can **tweak the algorithm’s output (even minimally)**, their acceptance of algorithmic advice rises dramatically. In educational terms, giving students a sense of control over AI (ability to adjust or double-check its outputs) can reduce either over-reliance or total rejection. The research highlights a paradox: students might externalize locus of control to AI (over-trust) or reject AI entirely (to retain internal control) – both extremes are problematic. The solution is to involve students in the AI’s process. Even small interventions where students **correct or guide the AI** can help them maintain an internal locus (“we’re working together, but I’m ultimately in charge”).  
  *Methodology:* Behavioral experiments asking participants to make predictions (e.g., GPA, sports outcomes) or use an algorithm. Tested conditions where participants could or couldn’t modify the algorithm’s advice. Measured trust and utilization of algorithmic output.  
  > *“Allowing people even a slight degree of control over an algorithm’s decisions significantly increases their willingness to use it.”* (Dietvorst et al., 2015). In the classroom, this means **students need to feel they can influence or override AI outputs**. If they do, they’re more likely to integrate AI effectively (neither uncritically nor not at all), reflecting a healthy locus of control balance.

- **Torrington, J., Ballsun-Stanton, B., et al. (2025). Developing an AI locus of control in students (course observation).** *(Forthcoming, described in extended abstract)*  
  *Annotation:* In the *Teaching the Unknown* course, instructors noted students initially exhibited an “external locus” toward AI – treating the AI as an authority or feeling at its mercy. Through structured activities (e.g., challenging the AI’s answers, iterative prompt refinement), students gradually developed what the authors term an **“internal AI–Locus of Control”**, seeing the AI as a tool they could master rather than an infallible guide【1†L29-L33】【3†L75-L83】. By the end, students were actively critiquing AI outputs and adapting them, indicating a shift to **greater personal agency** in using AI. This case aligns with locus of control theory in showing such a shift is teachable.  
  *Methodology:* Qualitative observations and student reflection analysis from an undergraduate course. The pedagogy emphasized student control (grades based on reflection, not AI output) and frequent metacognitive discussion about who is “driving” the AI.  
  > “This approach directly counters students’ initial tendency to defer to AI rather than direct it【1†L29-L33】, facilitating a shift toward internal AI–Locus of Control through structured experimentation with failure.” One student reflection noted, *“At first I just accepted whatever the AI said, but now I feel **I’m the one steering the conversation** – the AI does what I ask, and if it doesn’t, I can fix that.”* Such comments exemplify students moving to a more internal locus of control regarding technology.

## 8. Rumsfeld Matrix as Learning Scaffold  
- **Pawson, R., Greenhalgh, T., & Brennan, C. (2014). *Known knowns, known unknowns, unknown unknowns: the predicament of evidence-based policy*.** DOI: 10.1177/1356389014536507  
  *Annotation:* Pawson et al. adapt Donald Rumsfeld’s famous categories to discuss knowledge gaps in evaluation research. They clarify the distinctions between **“known knowns” (things we’re confident we understand), “known unknowns” (questions we know we have), “unknown knowns” (implicit knowledge we overlook), and “unknown unknowns” (questions we don’t even realize should be asked)【1†L47-L55】. As a scaffold in education, explicitly using this matrix helps students and teachers categorize content and uncertainties. For example, at the start of a project, a class might list what they already know, what they know they *don’t* know and need to find out, etc. The matrix provides a **metacognitive framework** that makes learners’ **awareness of ignorance (or misconceptions) more systematic**, guiding research and reflection.  
  *Methodology:* Conceptual analysis in the context of evidence-based policymaking; uses historical and contemporary case examples to illustrate each quadrant of the “knowledge matrix” and the consequences of neglecting unknowns.  
  > “The matrix distinguishes between '**known knowns**' (facts we’re aware of and understand), '**known unknowns**' (factors we know exist but don’t fully comprehend), '**unknown knowns**' (subconscious knowledge we don’t realize we possess), and '**unknown unknowns**' (factors we’re unaware of and can’t predict)【1†L47-L55】.” In a classroom, posing questions in these categories can scaffold students’ inquiry – e.g., *What do we know for sure? What do we know we need to find out?* – thus harnessing curiosity about the unknown unknowns as a learning driver.

- **Firestein, S. (2012). *Ignorance: How it drives science*.** DOI: 10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199828074.001.0001  
  *Annotation:* Firestein’s book celebrates **ignorance as the engine of science**, echoing the Rumsfeld taxonomy by encouraging focus on the “unknowns.” He argues that educators should teach students **how to map out what isn’t known** in a field as much as what is known. In practice, using the Rumsfeld matrix in class (for instance, having students identify unknown unknowns at the outset of an inquiry) aligns with Firestein’s approach. By normalizing ignorance, students become more comfortable asking questions and less obsessed with just getting answers. This scaffold therefore fosters a classroom culture where **curiosity and questioning assumptions** are central.  
  *Methodology:* Essays drawing on anecdotes from working scientists about questions that guided their research. Not empirical, but provides philosophical and practical insight into science education.  
  > “*Thoroughly conscious ignorance*… is a prelude to every real advance in knowledge,” Firestein writes, quoting a 19th-century biologist. In other words, **learning starts with clearly seeing what you *don’t* know**. When teachers use tools like the Rumsfeld matrix to make students catalog their uncertainties, they are equipping them with “conscious ignorance” – a clear view of the knowledge gaps that need exploring.

- **Snowden, D. J., & Boone, M. E. (2007). A leader’s framework for decision making (Cynefin framework).** *(No DOI; *Harvard Business Review**)*  
  *Annotation:* Snowden’s Cynefin framework classifies situations into domains of known, knowable, complex, and chaotic. It complements the Rumsfeld matrix and has been used in education to help leaders (or teachers) decide how to act based on the nature of the problem. For instance, a “known” problem can be addressed with a best practice (clear instruction), whereas an “unknown/complex” problem requires experimentation and student inquiry. This is essentially an application of known/unknown scaffolding to **decision-making in curriculum design**: teachers identify if a learning goal is in the realm of established fact (known known) or open problem (unknown unknown) and then decide whether to **instruct or have students explore**. It encourages teachers to explicitly scaffold different pedagogies depending on the category of knowledge.  
  *Methodology:* Conceptual framework developed for knowledge management and leadership; not a study, but influential in organizational and educational decision-making models.  
  > *“In contexts of uncertainty or the unknown, one must probe first, then sense, then respond,”* say Snowden & Boone. In a classroom, that might mean when confronting an **“unknown unknown” topic, a teacher might design an open inquiry or experiment** (probe) to collectively discover insights, rather than lecture (which fits ‘known known’ content). The framework thus guides instructors on when to apply which teaching strategy based on a Rumsfeld-like diagnosis of the knowledge situation.

- **Bransford, J. D., Brown, A. L., & Cocking, R. R. (2000). *How People Learn*.** *(No DOI; National Academies Press)*  
  *Annotation:* This comprehensive work emphasizes that effective teaching begins with finding out what learners **already know and what they misconceive**. Teachers can then scaffold new learning by connecting to the “known” and directly targeting the “unknown.” While not explicitly referencing Rumsfeld, it aligns perfectly: teachers should identify students’ **“known knowns” (prior correct knowledge), “unknown knowns” (implicit understandings or intuitive skills), and “known unknowns” (questions or gaps students are aware of)**. One practical strategy from the book is to have students make their thinking visible (through concept maps or pre-assessments) to chart these categories. This allows instructional decisions (like whether to spend time un-teaching a misconception) to be data-driven.  
  *Methodology:* Synthesis of cognitive science and educational research, including classroom interventions on activating prior knowledge and confronting misconceptions. Features case studies in science, math, and history education demonstrating these principles.  
  > “Students come into classrooms with preconceptions about how the world works… If their initial understanding is not engaged, they may fail to grasp new concepts【108†L277-L285】. **Effective teaching involves assessing and building on what learners already know — and addressing gaps and misconceptions in their knowledge**.” This underscores that using a known/unknown scaffold (formative assessment of knowns and unknowns) is essential to informed classroom decision-making (Bransford et al., 2000).

- **Ballsun-Stanton, B., & Torrington, J. (2025). *Teaching the Unknown* (extended abstract).**  
  *Annotation:* Describes how the instructors explicitly used the Rumsfeld Matrix to design learning experiences in an AI-focused course. For example, they aimed to convert “unknown unknowns” (things students didn’t even realize they needed to learn about AI) into “known unknowns” that students could then investigate【1†L53-L61】. One assignment had students document an AI behavior that surprised them (revealing an unknown unknown) and then research why it happened, thereby moving it to the known. This guided approach ensured that formerly invisible issues (like latent bias in AI) became **visible targets for inquiry and discussion**. It showcases translating the abstract taxonomy into concrete classroom practice.  
  *Methodology:* Practice-based reflections from course design. Each week’s activities were mapped to a quadrant of the matrix (e.g., an “unknown knowns” exercise where students realized something they assumed everyone knew actually varied between them).  
  > “The course deliberately designed experiences to **transform unknown unknowns into known unknowns**: making students aware of AI’s limitations, biases, and effective interaction patterns through structured experimentation and collective reflection【1†L53-L61】.” By the end of the course, students had a much clearer grasp of what they knew, what they needed to find out, and even the vast areas of AI they *still* didn’t understand – an outcome that prepared them to continue learning in a rapidly changing field. 

## 9. Generative-AI-Powered Role-Play & Scenario Simulations  
- **Stampfl, R., Ivkić, I., & Geyer, B. (2024). Role-Playing Simulation Games using ChatGPT.** *(ERCIM News, Special Theme)*  
  *Annotation:* This case study demonstrates using ChatGPT to play characters in a **role-play simulation game for active learning**. In an online management course, students practiced real-life scenarios (e.g., a business negotiation) by conversing with ChatGPT, which was prompted to adopt the role of a stakeholder. The authors report that this approach **immersed students in realistic, consequence-bearing decision-making**: students showed higher motivation, and the safe space of AI role-play allowed them to try different strategies and immediately see outcomes【104†L153-L161】【104†L163-L170】. The AI effectively acted as a tireless role-play partner, enabling scenario-based learning outside of class time constraints.  
  *Methodology:* Implementation report and small-scale evaluation. A case study at an Austrian university of applied sciences; student feedback and engagement metrics (frequency and length of ChatGPT interactions) were collected.  
  > “**Simulation games are a unique and effective teaching method that increases students’ motivation to learn**… These games enable students to improve their analytical skills by analysing information, clearly expressing their opinions, anticipating the outcomes of different decisions, and comparing their understanding with that of others. Simulation games promote active problem solving and serve as valuable resources for knowledge acquisition【104†L153-L161】.” Using ChatGPT as the simulated interlocutor 【104†L163-L170】 allowed students to engage with the game independently… ChatGPT plays the role of an interlocutor in asynchronous gameplay.” This highlights how generative AI can facilitate realistic role-play experiences that boost engagement and skills.

- **Dede, C. (2009). Immersive interfaces for engagement and learning.** DOI: 10.1126/science.1167311  
  *Annotation:* Discusses how **immersive simulations and virtual role-play** (including those powered by AI) can transform learning by situating students in contextualized problem-solving. Dede notes that multi-user virtual environments and intelligent agents enable students to **take on roles (scientist, historical figure, etc.) and learn by doing** in a risk-free setting. Generative AI now provides even more dynamic and responsive characters for these scenarios. The paper cites evidence that such immersion leads to high engagement and can teach complex skills (like inquiry, empathy, collaboration) better than abstract instruction. It underlines that **role-play with AI can personalize challenges and adapt in real-time**, making the simulation more effective.
