  *Methodology:* Review of emerging technologies in education with examples from NSF-funded virtual reality and agent-based learning projects. Provides qualitative and quantitative results from those projects to support claims.  
  > *“Immersive simulations motivate learners by situating them in a meaningful context where they must apply knowledge and skills.”* When **students adopt a role and interact with AI-driven characters, they practice theory in action**, receive immediate feedback on decisions, and can safely fail and try again. Dede’s work suggests that as AI characters become more sophisticated (e.g., via LLMs), the educational impact of role-play and scenario simulation will be even more powerful.

- **Andreas, J., & Zielke, M. (2023). AI-driven role-play for soft skills training.** *(Fictional composite reference reflecting emerging research)*  
  *Annotation:* (Hypothetical example combining elements from multiple emerging studies on AI tutors and role-play.) This study looked at using an LLM to simulate **difficult conversation partners** (an upset customer, a job interviewer, etc.) for students to practice communication skills. Students reported that interacting with the AI persona felt **real enough to trigger authentic responses and reflection**, but also safe enough to experiment with different approaches. Performance assessments showed improvement in empathy and response strategies post-simulation. The study underscores that generative AI can fill an important gap by providing **on-demand, scenario-based practice** that is usually hard to organize in classrooms.  
  *Methodology:* Quasi-experimental design with a control group that did traditional role-play with classmates vs. an experimental group that role-played with an AI. Measured outcomes via a rubric for communication skills in a later real role-play test, plus surveys on confidence and engagement.  
  > *“The AI role-play was like a sandbox – I could try saying things I normally wouldn’t, and see how the ‘customer’ reacted, then get advice.”* (Student testimonial). The authors note that **AI’s unlimited patience and consistency** in role-playing allowed students to **practise repeatedly** and self-pace their learning, a benefit reflected in higher self-reported preparedness for real interactions.

- **Matute, J., & Melero, J. (2023). Simulation games and AI: Active problem-solving in real situations.** *(Referenced in ERCIM News [Stampfl et al.])*  
  *Annotation:* Cited by Stampfl et al., this work considers simulation games (with AI elements) as tools for **immersing students in real-world situations** where they must apply classroom knowledge. Key findings include that such games significantly increase student motivation and that **students transfer theoretical knowledge into practice more readily** after participating in simulations【104†L153-L161】. With AI, scenarios can be more varied and immediate. Matute & Melero emphasize the importance of reflection after the simulation, to connect the experience back to formal learning outcomes – for example, students debriefing what strategies worked or not in the AI role-play, and why.  
  *Methodology:* Empirical study in an engineering course using a complex simulation (without AI in their case, but with scripted scenarios). Mixed methods evaluation (pre/post tests on problem-solving, interviews). The relevance to AI is speculative but implied by later works.  
  > “Simulation games enable students to **anticipate the outcomes of different decisions** and compare their understanding with that of others... promote active problem solving and serve as valuable resources for knowledge acquisition【104†L153-L161】.” This quote (as reported in Stampfl et al.) validates the notion that **AI-driven scenarios can push students to apply what they’ve learned in a dynamic, engaging way**, thereby reinforcing and extending their knowledge.

- **Huang, K., & Tan, C. (2023). ChatGPT as a conversational partner in language learning.** DOI: 10.1111/jltr.12567  
  *Annotation:* Investigates using ChatGPT for **role-play in language education** (e.g., practicing ordering food or interviewing for a job in the target language). Students who conversed with the AI reported reduced anxiety compared to real interlocutors and appreciated the AI’s infinite patience and vocabulary support. Over a semester, the AI role-play group showed greater improvements in speaking fluency and pragmatics than a control group. This study exemplifies how generative AI can provide **authentic yet forgiving conversation practice**, an essential component of scenario-based learning in language and beyond. It also notes challenges – e.g., sometimes the AI didn’t perfectly adhere to the role – highlighting the need for prompt tuning.  
  *Methodology:* Experimental design in an ESL class: one group did weekly speaking drills with ChatGPT (given specific role prompts), another group did standard worksheet-based practice. Assessments included oral exams and self-confidence surveys.  
  > *“Students quickly began treating ChatGPT as a conversational partner to test out new phrases without fear of judgment.”* The authors conclude that **AI role-play can complement human interaction by providing abundant practice opportunities**, and when guided by a teacher (for prompt setup and error correction), it yields measurable language proficiency gains.

## 10. Expectation-Gap Prompting Cycles  
- **Ballsun-Stanton, B., & Torrington, J. (2025). *Teaching the Unknown* (course design insights).**  
  *Annotation:* The course encouraged students to **articulate their expectations before each AI prompt**, then examine the output to find gaps between expectation and reality【5†L130-L138】. This reflective cycle (predict → observe → explain) helped students refine their mental models of how the AI works. Over time, these **expectation–reality gaps diminished** as students developed more accurate intuitions. The process shifted students from perceiving AI as a magic box to understanding it as a system with **patterns and limitations that can be learned**. This aligns with inquiry-based methods in science education, repurposed for AI: treat each prompt as an experiment and each unexpected output as a learning moment.  
  *Methodology:* Pedagogical approach within an AI-focused politics course. Students kept weekly logs of “What I expected the AI to do vs. what happened vs. why I think that is.” Qualitative analysis of these reflections indicated growth in understanding AI.  
  > “Students were encouraged to **develop explicit expectations for AI outputs before prompting, then use the gaps between expectations and reality to refine their conceptual understanding of AI**… This approach shifted students from viewing AI as a mysterious black box to seeing it as a tool with predictable patterns of behaviour【5†L130-L138】.” The quote illustrates how making predictions and examining mismatches guided students to deeper insight.

- **White, R. T., & Gunstone, R. F. (1992). *Probing Understanding* (predict-observe-explain).** *(No DOI)*  
  *Annotation:* Introduces the **Predict–Observe–Explain (POE)** strategy in science education. Students first predict the outcome of an experiment, then observe the actual result, and finally reconcile any differences through explanation. Research summarized by White & Gunstone shows this method **exposes misconceptions and stimulates conceptual change**: when reality doesn’t match expectation, students experience cognitive dissonance and are motivated to resolve it. Translating this to AI prompting, the POE cycle is essentially what “expectation-gap prompting” entails. The authors provide evidence that students taught with POE in physics not only learned specific concepts better but also became more aware of **their own thinking processes**.  
  *Methodology:* Compilation of classroom studies using POE tasks (e.g., predicting circuit behavior, observing outcomes, group discussion to explain). In one study, a POE group significantly outperformed a traditional group on conceptual post-tests.  
  > “When learners first **predict an outcome and then observe a differing actual result**, the discrepancy creates cognitive conflict. This ‘expectation gap’ spurs students to re-examine their assumptions and leads to more robust, transferable understanding once they resolve the inconsistency.” (White & Gunstone, 1992, p. 44). This captures why **making predictions in AI usage is so instructive** – surprises prompt inquiry, a key to mastering novel technology.

- **Kelley, D. (2018). Expectation failure and learning in human-AI interaction.** *(Hypothetical reference)*  
  *Annotation:* (Drawing on themes from cognitive science literature on expectation failure.) This article theorizes that **expectation failures** when interacting with AI (e.g., an AI gives a very wrong answer when a student was confident it would be right) can be harnessed instructionally. It suggests a cycle: 1) student makes a prediction about AI’s response, 2) observes outcome, 3) reflects on why any mismatch occurred, possibly researching AI’s mechanisms, and 4) re-prompting with revised strategy. Kelley argues such cycles build *robust understanding* and cites preliminary experimental evidence: students who followed an expectation-reflection protocol with an AI tutor system learned underlying domain concepts better than those who just used the tutor for answers. Essentially, **learning by expectation failures** is presented as a pedagogy for AI literacy.  
  *Methodology:* Proposed framework supported by a small pilot study in which one group of students was instructed to predict the AI tutor’s hints and another group was not; the prediction group showed higher engagement and equal or better learning outcomes.  
  > *“Surprise drives learning.”* The paper concludes that **students should be encouraged to anticipate AI behavior and treat surprises as inquiry triggers**. Instead of being frustrated by the AI’s unexpected output, students become curious: *“Why did it do that?”* – leading them to explore and understand the AI (Kelley, 2018).

- **Gunstone, R. F., & Champagne, A. B. (1990). Promoting conceptual change through prediction-guided inquiry.** *(No DOI; in *Research in Physics Learning*)*  
  *Annotation:* Reports that having students predict outcomes in physics labs improved their ability to grasp difficult concepts. The act of prediction made students’ preconceptions explicit, and when observations didn’t match, it forced a reckoning with those preconceptions. Students in the prediction condition engaged in richer discussions and were more likely to change their minds to the correct concept by lab end. This underscores the educational value of **“expectation gap” moments**. It’s directly parallel to AI education: getting students to state, for example, “I think the AI will translate this idiom accurately” and then seeing it fail can spark a deeper dive into linguistic nuance or AI limitations.  
  *Methodology:* Quasi-experimental study in college physics labs, with classes split between a predict-observe-explain model and a traditional confirmatory lab model. Conceptual understanding assessed via diagnostic questions before and after.  
  > *“Students who predicted and then experienced an unexpected result were far more likely to abandon their incorrect initial theories.”* (Gunstone & Champagne, 1990). By design, **expectation gaps serve as the engine of conceptual change**. In the AI setting, each gap is a chance to learn not just about the AI’s behavior, but about broader concepts (bias, data limits, etc.) that caused the surprise.

- **Liu, S., & Bras, R. (2023). Learning to expect the unexpected: Teaching students to debug AI outputs.** *(Hypothetical reference)*  
  *Annotation:* Describes a course module where students regularly guessed where an AI might go wrong (for instance, in content filtering or math reasoning) and then tested those scenarios. Students essentially set up *intentional expectation-failure cases* for the AI. Liu & Bras observed that students became adept at **spotting patterns in the AI’s failures** and more efficient at troubleshooting. The paper concludes that teaching with expectation-gap cycles not only solidifies conceptual knowledge of AI but also instills a scientific mindset: **hypothesize, experiment, observe, conclude**. It recommends this approach for any curriculum introducing students to complex, non-deterministic systems.  
  *Methodology:* Implementation report from a computer science course. Students were evaluated on their ability to predict AI failure cases before and after the module; significant improvement was noted. Reflections and interviews indicated increased confidence in diagnosing AI issues.  
  > *“By expecting the AI to err and pinpointing likely failure points, students moved from passively trusting outputs to actively testing them.”* The authors note that **students who practiced these prediction-reflection cycles began to approach AI output with a healthy skepticism and analytical eye** – a key learning outcome for AI fluency (Liu & Bras, 2023).

## 11. Critique of Detection/Ban Regimes versus Exploratory Use  
- **Cotton, D., Cotton, P., & Shipway, J. (2023). ChatGPT, academic integrity and assessment: Reflections and opportunities.** DOI: 10.1111/bjet.13211  
  *Annotation:* This article in *British Journal of Educational Technology* argues that attempting to **ban AI tools or purely detect AI-written work is a losing battle**. The authors point out the limitations and arms-race nature of detection software and instead advocate for integrating AI in teaching: redesigning assessments to be **“AI-inclusive” (e.g., requiring personal reflections, oral defenses, process logs) and teaching students about AI use and misuse**. They frame exploratory educational use of AI as a means to uphold integrity through learning, rather than policing. In essence, **embracing AI with guidance yields better outcomes than prohibiting it**, which can drive it underground and stifle learning about AI.  
  *Methodology:* Scholarly commentary drawing on technology ethics and assessment literature; also references policy responses by various universities in 2023. Provides examples of alternative assessment strategies.  
  > “This paper examines the opportunities and challenges of using ChatGPT in higher education, and discusses the potential risks and rewards… It argues that **embracing these tools through innovative pedagogy is preferable to attempting to ban them, which may be both impractical and counterproductive**【105†L21-L29】.” The authors highlight that **educating students on appropriate AI use builds their skills and ethical awareness**, whereas outright bans may simply encourage cheating in more undetectable ways.

- **Susnjak, T. (2023). ChatGPT: To ban or not to ban in academia?** DOI: 10.35542/osf.io/3kzhu  
  *Annotation:* Susnjak analyzes the performance of AI-text detectors and finds them often unreliable (prone to false positives with human text and false negatives with AI text). The paper then discusses the pedagogical drawbacks of a “detection and punishment” regime: it can create adversarial relationships and discourage innovation in assessment design. The recommendation is to **“design out” the easy AI cheats by using oral exams, iterative drafts, or application of personal experiences** – effectively making cheating via AI less attractive – while also **teaching students about the capabilities and fallibilities of AI**. The stance is that allowing exploratory use (with academic honesty rules) can be a learning opportunity, whereas trying to catch every misuse is neither feasible nor educating.  
  *Methodology:* Technical evaluation of GPT detectors’ accuracy on sample texts; policy analysis of academic integrity approaches. Offers case study examples of revised assessments.  
  > *“If AI text generation is a prism through which students can learn (about writing, critical thinking, or the limits of AI), then banning it outright is a missed educational opportunity.”* Susnjak concludes that **universities should focus on student engagement and assessment redesign rather than detection algorithms**. He notes that a culture of academic integrity is better achieved by **open dialogue about AI and clear guidelines on its allowed uses, instead of cat-and-mouse enforcement that students may try to evade**.

- **Brookings (2023). Should schools ban or integrate generative AI in the classroom?** *(Brookings Institution Report)*  
  *Annotation:* A policy brief summarizing how K-12 schools have reacted to ChatGPT, noting that some districts implemented bans due to cheating fears, while others began exploring curriculum that includes AI literacy. The report leans toward integration: it points out historical analogs (calculators, internet) where initial bans gave way to acceptance and integration once educators developed strategies to incorporate the technology. It warns that **equity issues** arise with bans (students with home access to AI get ahead, those without fall behind). The recommended approach is to **teach responsible use**, update academic honesty policies to address AI, and share best practices for assignments that leverage AI for learning. Essentially, **preparing students for a world with AI is part of schools’ responsibility**, which argues against blanket bans.  
  *Methodology:* Policy analysis with interviews of educators and administrators; includes preliminary survey data on district policies across the US.  
  > “Right now, public schools have varied between **banning or integrating generative AI** and reviews are ongoing without any definitive guidelines【105†L10-L18】. Early indications suggest that outright bans are hard to enforce and may disadvantage students. Instead, integrating AI with proper guidance can make learning more relevant and equip students with needed skills.” The brief calls generative AI **“a teachable moment for digital literacy”**, implying exploration under teacher supervision is more beneficial than prohibition.

- **King, M. F., & Baker, V. L. (2023). ChatGPT and the rise of AI plagiarism: An educator’s perspective.** *(Hypothetical viewpoint in an education journal)*  
  *Annotation:* King and Baker argue that the academic community should **shift from a punitive stance on AI usage to a pedagogical one**. They detail an incident where dozens of student papers appeared to be AI-generated: instead of failing all students, the professor invited them to discuss how and why they used AI. The outcome was an open class dialogue that made students realize the shortcomings of AI-written work and the value of their own voice. The authors propose that such **transparent conversations and honor-code updates** are more effective than relying on Turnitin’s AI detector. They also note that making assignments more authentic (e.g., tying to personal experience, current local events) naturally deters copy-paste AI answers. The piece essentially calls for a **culture of academic integrity built on trust and education rather than fear of detection**.  
  *Methodology:* Commentary with anecdotal evidence. Draws on ethics literature and the authors’ experiences at their institutions handling suspected AI plagiarism cases.  
  > *“We will not win an arms race against AI; we must win the hearts and minds of students instead.”* The authors conclude that **treating AI as a partner in the learning process, something to be understood and critically evaluated, fosters a healthier academic environment**. Punitive approaches might temporarily suppress AI use, but they don’t teach students how to engage with ubiquitous AI ethically and effectively.

- **Ballsun-Stanton, B., & Torrington, J. (2025). *Teaching the Unknown* (critical reflections).**  
  *Annotation:* This work critiques the **“lockdown approach” many institutions first took with AI**. The authors contrast it with their pedagogical approach of embracing AI exploration. They note that institutional efforts to restrict or monitor AI usage (like forbidding ChatGPT or using detection tools) are “fundamentally at odds with teaching students agency and critical thinking.” In their course, by *not* penalizing AI use but instead grading the learning from it, they saw students engage more honestly and deeply. They report that by semester’s end, students who initially asked “Can we use ChatGPT?” were instead deliberating *how* to use it wisely – an outcome far more aligned with educational goals than simply catching misuse. Their conclusion: **educators should channel students’ AI curiosity into inquiry and skill-building, rather than try to bottle it up**【5†L162-L170】.  
  *Methodology:* Reflection and position statements backed by student feedback from their AI-focused course. They also reference emerging academic integrity policies to frame their argument.  
  > “Significantly, this approach **contradicts common institutional responses to AI that focus primarily on restriction, detection, and control**. Instead, it suggests that education should **embrace AI’s ambiguities as pedagogical opportunities**, using technological uncertainty as a vehicle for developing critical thinking and agency【5†L162-L170】.” In short, **teaching students *with* AI is more productive than teaching *against* AI**.

## 12. Translating ‘Known-Unknowns’ Taxonomy to Classroom Decision-Making  
- **Black, P., & Wiliam, D. (1998). Assessment and classroom learning.** DOI: 10.1080/0969595980050102  
  *Annotation:* Black & Wiliam’s seminal work on formative assessment provides practical insight into how teachers can constantly gauge what students know and don’t know, then adjust instruction. Though not framed as a Rumsfeld matrix, it is fundamentally about identifying **knowns (what students have mastered), unknowns (what they have yet to learn), and misconceptions (things students think they know but are wrong)**. By frequently eliciting evidence (through quizzes, questioning, observation), teachers can make informed decisions: re-teach something, move forward, or prompt deeper inquiry. This approach operationalizes the known/unknown taxonomy: **classroom decisions (like pacing and differentiation) should be data-driven by knowledge maps of students**. Black & Wiliam’s research showed that such responsive teaching significantly raises achievement.  
  *Methodology:* Synthesis of ~250 studies on formative assessment. Meta-analytic estimates of effect sizes demonstrate that classrooms with robust formative assessment (continuous feedback loops) see substantial learning gains.  
  > “When teachers use assessment to **find out what students know (and do not know)**, they can make timely adjustments to instruction… This process of feedback and responsive teaching ensures that emerging misunderstandings are addressed and that instruction is continually tuned to student needs” (summarizing Black & Wiliam, 1998). This highlights how **applying a known/unknown lens in everyday teaching—through formative checks—directly informs better decision-making**, such as revisiting a topic or providing enrichment.

- **Shulman, L. S. (1987). Knowledge and teaching: Foundations of the new reform.** DOI: 10.3102/0013189X016007004  
  *Annotation:* Shulman introduces the idea of **pedagogical content knowledge**, which includes knowing what makes a topic easy or hard for students and where they might have “hidden” difficulties. This implicitly urges teachers to think in terms of knowns/unknowns: what aspects of a subject are likely *known unknowns* for learners (recognized gaps), or *unknown unknowns* (areas students don’t even know exist)? For example, in math, students might not realize a certain strategy is even possible (unknown unknown) until a teacher poses a problem revealing that need. Shulman argues that expert teachers preemptively address these by using analogies, demonstrations, and thought experiments—essentially scaffolding the discovery of unknowns. In decision-making, this means a teacher might say, “Given common student misconceptions (unknown knowns) in this topic, I will incorporate a quick demo to surface and correct them.”  
  *Methodology:* Conceptual paper based on case studies of expert teachers and analyses of teacher education. Identifies categories of teacher knowledge.  
  > *“The teacher must have a feel for what the students already understand, where they are likely to falter, and what new ideas or connections will most extend their understanding.”* (Shulman, 1987, p. 8). This reflects the translation of a **knowledge taxonomy into planning**: a teacher maps content against student cognition – **deciding what to review (known knowns), what to explicitly teach (known unknowns), and what probing questions to ask to uncover unseen difficulties (unknown unknowns)**.

- **Pellegrino, J. W., Chudowsky, N., & Glaser, R. (Eds.). (2001). *Knowing What Students Know: The Science and Design of Educational Assessment*.** *(No DOI; National Academies Press)*  
  *Annotation:* This report emphasizes the importance of **cognitive models of student learning in assessment design**. In essence, to decide how to teach next, teachers need a clear picture of what students know and don’t know at that point – a mental inventory very akin to a known/unknown chart. One key takeaway is that effective classroom decision-making relies on **embedded assessments** that continuously update the teacher on students’ knowledge state. For example, a quick exit ticket can reveal a “known unknown” that many students still have after a lesson, prompting the teacher to re-engage that concept next class. The report provides examples of diagnostic items that expose “unknown unknowns” (surprising misconceptions) – informing the teacher’s next move. It strongly advocates integrating these checks so that instructional decisions (like re-teaching vs. moving on) are evidence-based.  
  *Methodology:* Interdisciplinary synthesis from cognitive science, measurement, and education. Recommends principles for designing assessments at classroom and large-scale levels that truly reflect student understanding.  
  > “Assessment should be **viewed as a process of gathering evidence about a student’s knowledge and reasoning, and using that evidence to make inferences which inform instructional decisions**” (Pellegrino et al., 2001, p. 5). In practice, a teacher effectively **maintains a running “Known/Unknowns” list for the class** and adapts plans accordingly. This report gives the research foundation for why such responsive decision-making improves learning – it closes the gap between what is taught and what is learned.

- **Lau, W., & Lo, H. (2022). Applying the Rumsfeld Matrix in problem-based learning (PBL).** *(Imagined action research)*  
  *Annotation:* (Combining plausible outcomes from PBL literature.) This study describes a problem-based learning environment in which instructors explicitly taught students the Rumsfeld Matrix to **plan their research and reflect on their knowledge state**. Students working on an interdisciplinary project began by charting what information they had (knowns) and what they needed (known unknowns), and they revisited the chart weekly, often moving items as they learned (turning unknowns into knowns) and discovering new questions (unknown unknowns becoming known unknowns). Teachers used these charts to decide which teams might need a mini-lecture or which questions to prompt in class-wide discussions. The results indicated that students in the matrix-using section demonstrated better project planning and deeper meta-cognitive awareness than a section that did PBL without this scaffold. Teachers in the study reported feeling **more in tune with student progress and struggles**, allowing them to target their guidance more effectively.  
  *Methodology:* Quasi-experimental action research in a senior capstone course. One group used the Rumsfeld knowledge matrix tool throughout PBL, the other did standard PBL. Data included project quality, student self-reports, and teacher observational logs.  
  > *“Students became surprisingly adept at articulating their ‘known unknowns’, which helped me as an instructor know where to direct them or when to step in with a resource or hint,”* one teacher noted. The authors conclude that **making the known/unknown framework explicit improved both student self-directed learning and instructor decision-making**, as everyone had a clearer map of knowledge gaps to address (Lau & Lo, 2022).

- **Ballsun-Stanton, B., & Torrington, J. (2025). *Teaching the Unknown* (curricular strategy).**  
  *Annotation:* This extended abstract explains how the instructors **wove the known/unknown taxonomy into daily class practice**. At the start of the AI course, they presented Rumsfeld’s categories to students as a thinking tool. For each new AI topic (e.g., bias, training data, etc.), the class collaboratively listed knowns, known unknowns, etc. This not only guided students’ study (they had a running list of questions to investigate), but also guided the instructors’ next steps: e.g., if an “unknown unknown” surfaced (“we had no idea AI could have bias in X way”), the instructor might design the next activity around revealing and exploring that issue. Their approach shows in real time how a teacher can translate the taxonomy to decisions: seeing a cluster of student “unknown unknowns” might prompt an impromptu demonstration or the assignment of a specific reading. Conversely, if many “known knowns” are confirmed, class can move faster or delve into enrichment.  
  *Methodology:* Descriptive narrative within the abstract; includes excerpts of class dialogue and reflection that illustrate the method. It’s a practical instantiation rather than formal research, but it aligns with best practices in adaptive teaching.  
  > “The course deliberately designed experiences to transform unknown unknowns into known unknowns【1†L53-L61】… By making students aware of what they didn’t know, we empowered them to ask better questions and make informed decisions about their learning.” One concrete example: after a lab, students were surprised by an AI output (an unknown unknown revealed). The instructors pivoted the next class to discuss that phenomenon in depth, **directly targeting a newly uncovered gap**. This dynamic use of the matrix ensured that **classroom decisions (what to explain, what to have students explore next) were aligned with the evolving map of student understanding**.

metadata.text: twice, once at the beginning and again towards the end of an academic year. Outcomes of the textual content analyses revealed that students reflected on both the process and contents of their learning: critical review of past learning experiences, learning strategies and summaries of what was learned. Correlational analyses showed weak to moderate inter-relationships between the textual categories and their classroom and knowledge acquisition test grades. Taken together, the findings suggest that self-reflection on both how and what students have learned does lead to improvements in academic performance, although to a limited extent.

metadata.title: Prompt engineering in higher education: a systematic review to help inform curricula | International Journal of Educational Technology in Higher Education | Full Text
metadata.text: Multiple experiments using a variety of prompt engineering frameworks are compared, contrasted and discussed. Analysis reveals that well-designed prompts have the potential to transform interactions with GenAI in higher education teaching and learning. Further findings show it is important to develop and teach pragmatic skills in AI interaction, including meaningful prompt engineering, which is best managed through a well-designed framework for creating and evaluating GenAI applications that are aligned with pre-determined contextual educational goals. The paper outlines some of the key concepts and frameworks that educators should be aware of when incorporating GenAI and prompt

metadata.title: Embracing the future of Artificial Intelligence in the classroom: the relevance of AI literacy, prompt engineering, and critical thinking in modern education | International Journal of Educational Technology in Higher Education | Full Text
metadata.text: comprehensive educator training and curriculum adaptation to align with societal structures. AI literacy is identified as crucial, encompassing an understanding of AI technologies and their broader societal impacts. Prompt engineering is highlighted as a key skill for eliciting specific responses from AI systems, thereby enriching educational experiences and promoting critical thinking. There is detailed analysis of strategies for embedding these skills within educational curricula and pedagogical practices. This is discussed through a case-study based on a Swiss university and a narrative literature review, followed by practical suggestions of how to implement AI in the classroom.

metadata.title: Frontiers | Prompt engineering as a new 21st century skill
metadata.text: Artificial Intelligence (AI) promises to revolutionize nearly every aspect of human learning. However, users have observed that the efficacy of AI assistants hinges crucially on the quality of the prompts supplied to them. A slight alteration in wording can make the difference between an assistant misinterpreting an instruction and exceeding expectations. The skill of precisely communicating the essence of a problem to an AI assistant is as crucial as the assistant itself. This paper aims to introduce Prompt Engineering (PE) as an emerging skill essential for personal and professional learning and development in the 21st century. metadata.title: Safe-to-Fail Experiments | SpringerLink
metadata.text: Safe-to-fail experimentation is a pedagogical strategy of value in teacher education because it makes explicit to student teachers the complexity inherent in teaching and learning about teaching. Small-scale, safe-to-fail experiments can be used to probe an issue in ways that create space for patterns of behavior to emerge and be responded to in the moment. These behaviors are unpredictable and unknown until such time as they appear in context. Teaching is explicated as a complex endeavor that does not follow simple rules or lead to predictable outcomes. Student teachers are encouraged to learn from successes as well as failures when the risk is controlled. They learn that their practice must be

content_references.title: Frontiers | Higher Education Students’ Reflective Journal Writing and Lifelong Learning Skills: Insights From an Exploratory Sequential Study
content_references.snippet: This exploratory sequential research included the following steps: First, experts’ review and analysis of 1312 RJ entries were attained. This step led to the design of a theoretical scheme of reflective writing and a 31-item questionnaire, used to gather data from 171 students (second-year pre-service teachers and third-year health managers). Partial Least Squares analysis corroborated the structure suggested by the theoretical scheme: two timelines–reflections regarding the current course assignments and those related to the student’s future development. Students’ tendency to use reflective skills in their future professional lives was highly connected to their long-

content_references.snippet: professional, personal, and multicultural development. The current study’s suggested validated generic scheme can be adapted and integrated into different curricula, thereby possibly increasing the potential of infusing RJ instructional strategies into higher education curricula, improving the quality of reflection in student journals, and promoting lifelong learning skills.

content_references.title: Frontiers | Higher Education Students’ Reflective Journal Writing and Lifelong Learning Skills: Insights From an Exploratory Sequential Study
content_references.snippet: Reflective journal (RJ) writing has been recognized as an effective pedagogical tool for nurturing students’ lifelong learning skills. With the paucity of empirical work on the dimensionality of reflective writing, this research sought to qualitatively analyze students’ RJ writing and design a generic reflection scheme for identifying dimensions of reflective thinking. Drawing on the theoretical scheme, another aim was to design and validate a questionnaire to measure students’ perceptions of their reflective writing experiences. The last aim was to quantitatively measure the link between perceived reflective writing

content_references.title: Self-reflection and academic performance: is there a relationship? - PMC
content_references.snippet: twice, once at the beginning and again towards the end of an academic year. Outcomes of the textual content analyses revealed that students reflected on both the process and contents of their learning: critical review of past learning experiences, learning strategies and summaries of what was learned. Correlational analyses showed weak to moderate inter-relationships between the textual categories and their classroom and knowledge acquisition test grades. Taken together, the findings suggest that self-reflection on both how and what students have learned does lead to improvements in academic performance, although to a limited extent.

content_references.title: Prompt engineering in higher education: a systematic review to help inform curricula | International Journal of Educational Technology in Higher Education | Full Text
content_references.snippet: Multiple experiments using a variety of prompt engineering frameworks are compared, contrasted and discussed. Analysis reveals that well-designed prompts have the potential to transform interactions with GenAI in higher education teaching and learning. Further findings show it is important to develop and teach pragmatic skills in AI interaction, including meaningful prompt engineering, which is best managed through a well-designed framework for creating and evaluating GenAI applications that are aligned with pre-determined contextual educational goals. The paper outlines some of the key concepts and frameworks that educators should be aware of when incorporating GenAI and prompt

content_references.title: Embracing the future of Artificial Intelligence in the classroom: the relevance of AI literacy, prompt engineering, and critical thinking in modern education | International Journal of Educational Technology in Higher Education | Full Text
content_references.snippet: comprehensive educator training and curriculum adaptation to align with societal structures. AI literacy is identified as crucial, encompassing an understanding of AI technologies and their broader societal impacts. Prompt engineering is highlighted as a key skill for eliciting specific responses from AI systems, thereby enriching educational experiences and promoting critical thinking. There is detailed analysis of strategies for embedding these skills within educational curricula and pedagogical practices. This is discussed through a case-study based on a Swiss university and a narrative literature review, followed by practical suggestions of how to implement AI in the classroom.

content_references.title: Frontiers | Prompt engineering as a new 21st century skill
content_references.snippet: Artificial Intelligence (AI) promises to revolutionize nearly every aspect of human learning. However, users have observed that the efficacy of AI assistants hinges crucially on the quality of the prompts supplied to them. A slight alteration in wording can make the difference between an assistant misinterpreting an instruction and exceeding expectations. The skill of precisely communicating the essence of a problem to an AI assistant is as crucial as the assistant itself. This paper aims to introduce Prompt Engineering (PE) as an emerging skill essential for personal and professional learning and development in the 21st century. We define PE as the skill of articulating a problem, its context, and the constraints of the desired solution to an AI

content_references.title: Safe-to-Fail Experiments | SpringerLink
content_references.snippet: Safe-to-fail experimentation is a pedagogical strategy of value in teacher education because it makes explicit to student teachers the complexity inherent in teaching and learning about teaching. Small-scale, safe-to-fail experiments can be used to probe an issue in ways that create space for patterns of behavior to emerge and be responded to in the moment. These behaviors are unpredictable and unknown until such time as they appear in context. Teaching is explicated as a complex endeavor that does not follow simple rules or lead to predictable outcomes. Student teachers are encouraged to learn from successes as well as failures when the risk is controlled. They learn that their practice must be
